bestBHT.bht: Are you so utterly ignorant of the spirit of Scripture? If you know what you are doing, you are blessed, but if you do not, you are accursed. Have you not even read this small point? Have you not read even this? This strong expression implies their utter ignorance of what the Scriptures meant. Jesus defends the disciples by pointing to the actions of David and the priests who performed seemingly forbidden tasks.

Henry Alford: Have ye not so much as this? i.e. ‘Are ye so utterly ignorant of the spirit of Scripture?’"
O man, if thou knowest what thou art doing, blessed art thou: but if thou knowest not, accursed, and a transgressor of the law."
This remarkable substitution seems to be an interpolation, but hardly an invention of a later time. Its form and contents speak for its originality, and, I am disposed to believe, its authenticity.
Marvin Vincent: Have ye not read [ουδε ανεγνωτε] ? The A. V. misses the force of ouJude : "have ye not so much as read?" Rev., "have ye not read even this?
Philip Schaff: Luke 6:3. Have ye not read even this? A strong expression (comp. Mark 12:10) implying their utter ignorance of what the Scriptures meant.
Archibald T. Robertson: Not even this (ουδε τουτο). This small point only in Luke.
John Gill: For they brought the charge against the disciples to him, being desirous to know what he would say, and that they might have something to accuse him of; and who, at once, took up the cause of his disciples, and vindicated them..."
...by observing what David did when he and his men were hungry; how that he went into the tabernacle, took the showbread, and ate of it, and gave it to his men..."
...taking notice of another instance, namely, how on the sabbath days the priests, by doing various servile works, profaned the sabbath day, and yet were not charged with any blame.

bhtAttempts.bht: Are you so utterly ignorant of the spirit of Scripture? If you know what you are doing, you are blessed, but if you do not, you are accursed and a transgressor of the law. Have you not even read this small point in Luke? Have you not read even this? This strong expression implies their utter ignorance of what the Scriptures meant. Consider the charge brought against the disciples, how Jesus defends them by pointing to the actions of David and the priests who, in their hunger and on the Sabbath, performed seemingly forbidden tasks without blame.
